items.title: AI-agent ethics should consider sentient non-human animals
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02796-0 AI-agent ethics should consider sentient non-human animals

items.title: China’s chikungunya virus outbreak is a wake up call
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02794-2 China’s chikungunya virus outbreak is a wake up call

items.title: Include climate impacts when protecting infrastructure
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02797-z Include climate impacts when protecting infrastructure

items.title: Veterinarians need to be part of West Nile disease storytelling
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02795-1 Veterinarians need to be part of West Nile disease storytelling

items.title: Unifiying gravity and quantum theory requires better understanding of time
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02756-8 Textbooks give strange, imprecise explanations of where things happen in quantum mechanics. Consistency with gravity needs a fresh approach.

items.title: Connectome-constrained ligand-receptor interaction analysis for understanding brain network communication
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 02 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63204-9 By modeling the brain communication as an optimal transport problem, CLRIA integrates structural and molecular data, and reveals the bias for hybrid strategy, asymmetric hierarchical signaling, and molecular perspective for state transitions.

items.title: Who is afraid of quantum mechanics? Books in brief
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02755-9 Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.

items.title: ‘The wolf is not the bad guy’: working with farmers to protect a reintroduced species
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02760-y Carmen García-Chávez monitors the activities of wolves after their reintroduction to Chihuahua, northern Mexico.

items.title: The grant lottery: award rates at UK national funding agency fall below 20%
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02584-w Application volume is outpacing available funding, intensifying competition and worsening pressure on the peer-review system. But those who win grants are now getting more.

items.title: How ageing changes our genes — huge epigenetic atlas gives clearest picture yet
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02735-z A map of DNA methylation changes in human organs could help researchers to discover more targets for anti-ageing therapies.

items.title: Do social-media bans benefit young people? These data could offer clues
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02759-5 Australia’s Online Safety Amendment Act provides the chance for researchers to analyse the complex relationship between social-media use and mental health in adolescents, but results should be interpreted with caution.

items.title: States now have a legal duty to prevent climate harm — justice is in reach
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02752-y A July ruling from the International Court of Justice is clear: nations can face consequences if they don’t act on the climate crisis.

items.title: Clarity or accuracy — what makes a good scientific image?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02757-7 Photography is not just illustrative, it is investigative. A revealing book cautions us to look closely at what pictures are really telling us.

items.title: Filamentous fungi control multiphase flow and fluid distribution in porous media
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03020-6 Filamentous fungi often grow in porous environments with multiphase flow. Now it is shown that these fungi can actively induce multiphase flow and mobilize trapped fluid phases in porous media.

items.title: Ferroaxial density wave from intertwined charge and orbital order in rare-earth tritellurides
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03008-2 The axial Higgs mode is theoretically attributed to a hidden ferroaxial component of charge order. In rare-earth tritellurides, this ferroaxial order is now shown to be induced by intertwined orbital and charge orders.

items.title: Structural basis for HIV-1 capsid adaption to a deficiency in IP6 packaging
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63363-9 IP6 is a critical host cofactor for HIV-1 assembly and infectivity. In this study, the authors uncover the structural basis by which HIV-1 adapts to a deficiency in IP6 packaging through a G225R mutation at the C-terminus of the capsid protein.

items.title: Catalytic aromatic C−H borylation via strained Si and Ge metallacycles
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63335-z Arenes bearing boryl and silyl or germyl groups possess unique reactivity and versatility, yet their synthesis often involves complex, multi-step procedures. Here, the authors present a highly efficient, single-step method for synthesizing ortho-boronated arylhydrosilanes and arylgermanes via catalytic C − H borylation reaction.

items.title: Longitudinal liquid biopsy identifies an early predictive biomarker of immune checkpoint blockade response in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63538-4 The response to immune checkpoint blockade in head and neck cancer has been heterogenous. Here, the authors utilise longitudinal sampling of a head and neck squamous cell carcinoma model to identify biomarkers of response.

items.title: Cryo-EM structures of CRAF/MEK1/14-3-3 complexes in autoinhibited and open-monomer states reveal features of RAF regulation
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63227-2 CRAF is one of three RAF-family kinases and is mutated in cancer and RASopathies. Jang et al. report structural and mechanistic studies of CRAF/MEK1/14-3-3 complexes that explain distinct features of CRAF regulation.

items.title: Single-molecule fluorescence microscopy reveals regulatory mechanisms of MYO7A-driven cargo transport in stereocilia of live inner ear hair cells
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63102-0 Miyoshi and colleagues propose STELLA-SPIM microscopy to visualise single MYO7A molecules in live murine inner ear hair cells. Their data suggest that MYO7A traffics as a dimer within stereocilia to assemble the mechanoelectrical transduction machinery.

items.title: Aerosol iodide accelerates reactive nitrogen cycling in the marine atmosphere
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63420-3 Iodide promotes HONO production during nitrate photolysis by influencing the surface enrichment of nitrate, accelerating reactive nitrogen cycling in the marine atmosphere.

items.title: Mature and migratory dendritic cells promote immune infiltration and response to anti-PD-1 checkpoint blockade in metastatic melanoma
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62878-5 The role of the tumour microenvironment in the response to immune checkpoint inhibitors in metastatic melanoma remains poorly understood. Here, single cell profiling of metastatic melanoma samples identifies associations of the mature dendritic enriched in immunoregulatory molecules subtype with immunotherapy response.

items.title: Peptide codes for organ-selective mRNA delivery
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02331-6 Tissue-specific mRNA or gene editing machinery delivery is achieved with lipid nanoparticles containing peptides with specific sequences, which tune the protein corona of the particles by mechanical optimization of peptide–protein binding affinities.

items.title: Tissue-specific mRNA delivery and prime editing with peptide–ionizable lipid nanoparticles
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02320-9 Peptide ionizable lipids containing specific amino acids and functional groups render lipid nanoparticles with the tissue-specific delivery of mRNA and prime editing systems, which can be useful for advanced mRNA-based therapeutics.

items.title: Energy harvesting across broad frequencies with a nonlinear Hall rectifier
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 01 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-01999-w Harvesting ambient electromagnetic energy requires broadband, low-power rectification, which is challenging to achieve with conventional diodes. Now, using the nonlinear Hall effect in thin films of the topological crystalline insulator SnTe, wireless, zero-bias rectification is demonstrated across megahertz to terahertz frequencies and with sensitivity down to ambient power levels.
